Cayley-Hamilton Theorem

Theorem. Every complex square matrix AAA satisfies its own characteristic equation: if pA(λ)=0p_A(\lambda) =0pA​(λ)=0 denotes the characteristic equation of AAA, then pA(A)=0p_A(A) = 0pA​(A)=0 also (replacing constants with constant multiples of the identity matrix).

Proof. (Partial, only for diagonalizable and diagonal matrices)

Case 1: diagonal matrices of the form

A=[λ10...00λ2...0⋮⋮⋱⋮00...λn].A = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0 & ... & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_2 & ... & 0 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & ... & \lambda_n \end{bmatrix}.A=⎣⎡​λ1​0⋮0​0λ2​⋮0​......⋱...​00⋮λn​​⎦⎤​.

The characteristic equation of AAA is given by det⁡(A−λI)=0\det(A - \lambda I) = 0det(A−λI)=0, or equivalently,

(λ1−λ)(λ2−λ)...(λn−λ)=0(\lambda_1 - \lambda)(\lambda_2 - \lambda) ...(\lambda_n-\lambda) = 0(λ1​−λ)(λ2​−λ)...(λn​−λ)=0

by Laplace expansion. Plugging in AAA into the equation and replacing λi\lambda_iλi​ with λiI\lambda_i Iλi​I gives

(λ1I−A)(λ2I−A)...(λnI−A)=0\begin{aligned} (\lambda_1 I - A)(\lambda_2 I- A) ... (\lambda_n I - A) = \mathbf{0}\\ \end{aligned}(λ1​I−A)(λ2​I−A)...(λn​I−A)=0​

which is a product of nnn diagonal matrices with the first diagonal term missing, the second term missing, etc., in that order. As multiplying diagonal matrices is equivalent to multiplying their terms, (λ1I−A)(λ2I−A)(\lambda_1 I - A)(\lambda_2 I - A)(λ1​I−A)(λ2​I−A) has its first two diagonal terms missing; multiplying that onto (λ3I−A)(\lambda_3 I - A)(λ3​I−A) results in a matrix with its third diagonal term missing; and so on and so forth, until the resulting product is a matrix with all its diagonal terms missing, i.e. the zero matrix.

Case 2: diagonalizable matrices. We have

P−1AP=DP^{-1}AP = DP−1AP=D

for some diagonal matrix DDD and transformation matrix PPP. As previously proven, similar matrices have the same characteristic equation; if AAA is similar to DDD, then DDD must satisfy the characteristic equation of AAA, pAp_ApA​. Hence

pA(D)=pA(P−1AP)=0p_A(D) = p_A(P^{-1} A P) = 0pA​(D)=pA​(P−1AP)=0

Suppose that pAp_ApA​ can be written as the polynomial ∑i=0nciλi\sum_{i=0}^{n} c_i \lambda^i∑i=0n​ci​λi. Then we have

∑i=0nci(P−1AP)i=0\sum_{i=0}^n c_i (P^{-1}AP)^i = 0i=0∑n​ci​(P−1AP)i=0

or, because of the following lemma:

Lemma. Powers of diagonalizable matrices. (P−1AP)i=P−1APP−1AP...P−1AP=P−1AiP(P^{-1} A P)^{i} = P^{-1}APP^{-1}AP...P^{-1}AP = P^{-1}A^iP(P−1AP)i=P−1APP−1AP...P−1AP=P−1AiP; this is useful in taking higher powers, as exponentiating a diagonal matrix is fairly easy.

We thus have

∑i=0nciP−1AiP=0P−1∑i=0nciAiP=0P−1(∑i=0nciAi)P=0∑i=0nciAi=0.\begin{aligned} \sum_{i=0}^n c_i P^{-1}A^iP &= 0 \\ P^{-1}\sum_{i=0}^n c_iA^i P &= 0 \\ P^{-1}(\sum_{i=0}^n c_iA^i)P &= 0 \\ \sum_{i=0}^n c_iA^i &= 0. \end{aligned}i=0∑n​ci​P−1AiPP−1i=0∑n​ci​AiPP−1(i=0∑n​ci​Ai)Pi=0∑n​ci​Ai​=0=0=0=0.​

Thus AAA satisfies its own characteristic equation.

Case 3: 2×22\times 22×2 matrices. As previously shown, all 2×22\times 22×2 matrices can be written as one of three canonical forms; the first two canonical forms are diagonal and are addressed in Case 1, with the final canonical form

B=[λ10λ]B = \begin{bmatrix} \lambda & 1 \\ 0 & \lambda \end{bmatrix}B=[λ0​1λ​]

having characteristic equation pB(z)=(λ−z)2p_B(z) = (\lambda-z)^2pB​(z)=(λ−z)2; pB(B)=0p_B(B) = 0pB​(B)=0, as is computationally verifiable.

Suppose that B=P−1APB = P^{-1} A PB=P−1AP again for some transformation matrix PPP and 2×22\times 22×2 matrix AAA. Then BBB and AAA have the same characteristic equation due to similarity. We also have

pB(B)=0=pA(P−1AP)=P−1pA(A)P\begin{aligned} p_B(B) = 0 &= p_A(P^{-1} A P) \\ &= P^{-1}p_A(A)P \end{aligned}pB​(B)=0​=pA​(P−1AP)=P−1pA​(A)P​

owing to derivations in the previous case, and thus pA(A)=0p_A(A) = 0pA​(A)=0.
